snippet: Three applications for a Hebrew charter school have been rejected, but, despite community outrage, the school has been given a federal grant and could open in September.
abstract: Michael Winerip On Education column notes that three applications have been rejected for proposed Hebrew charter school in New Brunswick, NJ, to be called Tikun Olam Hebrew Language Charter High School, but that school has received $600,000 grant from United States Education Department; argues that there are many good reasons for state to have rejected applications and questions how school gained federal approval.
lead_paragraph: Three applications for a Hebrew charter school have been rejected, but, despite community outrage, the school has been given a federal grant and could open in September.

headline.seo: Application for Hebrew Charter School in New Jersey Raises Concern
headline.main: Rejected 3 Times, School May Still Open Soon, and With a Grant, Too
headline.print_headline: Rejected 3 Times, School May Still Open Soon, And With a Grant, Too
